Steps to reproduce:

1. Join a muc as normal user
--> No contact pictures are shown even if the contacts are known and their pictures are shown in a normal chat. (You'll only see the Letters)

2. Ask the MUC admin for Mod privileges

body:
Jabber is a nice and cool alternative, unfortunately the servers out there are more than instable. Sometimes they are offline, sometimes messages can't be sent and are on hold for hours, sometimes they reject messages. Resulting from that to have a reliable connection to a chat partner, most people I know do have at least two accounts on two different servers.

Now handling these two accounts is a bit tricky and nothing that would be accepted by a user without technical skills (means the standard WhatsApp user).

So as a suggestion to overcome this problem: is it possible to offer a possibility to create one account in Conversations that internally handles two jabber-accounts on two different servers and always sends messages using the other server when the first one fails? I know this is already possible (manually) by having two separate accounts and identities in Conversations, but I think it would be much better to let Conversations automate this. Most of the "standard" users will not do this but need a simple and easy to use solution - and reliable connections that do work most of the time.
title: Concatenate two Jabber-servers into one tab in Conversations

When you are the admin of a conference chat room and you have set a topic for the room in Conversations, Conversations automatically updates the topic to that value everytime you log in. (Or at least it looks like that since the other clients I have connected to the conference notify me of the change.)

This is cumbersome for the clients that show topic changes and when the topic has not been changed since the last update, this update is unnecessary. 

Thus, I propose to compare the status that is stored in Conversations with the current status of the Conference and only publish a change when the two differ.

body:
Minor tweak to make the presences hash table final.

This is only partially my usual weirdness about things being final; we synchronize on the presences table a few times and it's unsafe to EVER sync on something that's not final (sync doesn't matter if the collection you're syncing on changes to a completely different collection in the middle of the operation).
title: Don't synchronize on non-final field

body:
PGP messages are only decrypted while the correspondent conversation is in foreground. Because of that
- Notifications are not meaningful
- Depending on the device, it takes quite a while to decrypt everything, especially if PGP messages where sent from another device with carbon-copy enabled.
As messages are decrypted in order, it is also impossible to continue communicating while waiting for the decryption to finish.

This patch adds a decryption service to the backend, which keeps track of the (un)locked state of the Keychain and manages the decryption. Old messages are decrypted in-order; new ones as they come in.
title: PGP messages background decryption

body:
XMPP servers don't always have the hostname (or the certificate) that corresponds to the domain name that is part of the userid. For example, the user might be user2@example.com, but the server might actually be chat.example.com. When this happens, Conversations rejects the server's TLS certificate since the server's hostname does not match the user's domain. Many XMPP clients allow the server hostname to be specified independently of the username for this situation.

A workaround is for the server's certificate to use the subjectAltName extension so that the user's domain is valid, though this may not always be possible.
title: Support server names that are different than UID domains

body:
When Conversations establishes a TLS connection to the server it sends the **username in the unencrypted part** of the TLS session establishment. This does not seem to be necessary as Pidgin, for example, doesn't do it. This is problematic as others on the network, e.g. in an unencrypted WiFi-hotspot or certain nation-state actors passively monitoring backbone links, get to know the identity behind an IP address and a device leading to a loss of privacy.

Here are two session establishments trace excerpts captured with Wireshark:

![username-before-tls](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3988874/9975707/65fa0c14-5ec6-11e5-9284-5db710d35933.png)
title: Username is leaked during TLS connection establishment

body:
I am currently experimenting with a local DNSSEC aware validating resolver, and managed to compile Unbound for Android KitKat (with help from a project here on github). 

To make use of DNSSEC validation, DNS queries from all services and apps must be sent to the local resolver at 127.0.0.1 and/or ::1, respectively, rather than the ones configured via DHCP. On Android 4.4, this can be achieved with a small script that must be run right after connecting to Wifi/Mobile Network, or with a working DNS changer app (could not find any).

Once ::1 is set as resolver, almost all apps query the local validating resolver, except "Ping & DNS" (a network diagnostic tool), and Conversations. Conversations seems to bypass the system settings, and still queries the nameservers configured via DHCP.

I would suggest that Conversations better use the standard Android API for DNS queries, to be compatible not only with setups like mine but also with various DNS changer apps.
title: Unusual handling of DNS queries

body:
According to the XEP, under "Communicating the Checksum or Hashing Algorithm" , although no specific algorithm is mentioned, the example given for file transfers uses the SHA-1 hashing algorithm:
```
<hash xmlns='urn:xmpp:hashes:1' algo='sha-1'>552da749930852c69ae5d2141d3766b1</hash>
```

I'm not sure if this is used as an integrity or security checksum, but there are collision attacks against SHA-1 which reduce bruteforcing it to 2^60 time. This is significantly weaker than the 128-bits of security provided by AES-128-GMC, and judging by past history hashing functions will probably degrade faster than symmetric ciphers. I understand the attack vectors are limited but I think at least SHA-256 should be used.
title: OMEMO file encryption uses SHA1

body:
When I have my AFWall+ firewall turned on (iptables) and all traffic routed via my VPN, Conversations is unable to connect.

After much debugging I've found that Conversations is making direct DNS requests.  From what I've gathered from the AFWall+ [wiki](https://github.com/ukanth/afwall/wiki/DNS#commands-to-check-if-dns-is-working) and [issues](https://github.com/ukanth/afwall/issues/18) this is intentionally disabled, and in fact it is undesirable to allow these requests when the VPN is connected, therefore it is [disabled when the firewall is enabled](https://github.com/ukanth/afwall/wiki/FAQ#14-udp-port-53-dns-is-blocked-if-whitelisting-mode-is-enabled-why).

I've found that when the VPN is connected all other apps are resolving via the system DNS service and are able to successfully resolve names via the DNS provided inside the VPN.

Conversations on the other hand is making DNS requests directly to the pre-VPN configured resolver outside the VPN.  These are being blocked and thus Conversations is unable to connect to the XMPP server.

The expected behaviour would be for Conversations to resolve names via the system resolver, thereby not leaking information and functioning correctly regardless of how routing and tunnelling are set up.
title: DNS requests done directly instead of via the system resolver

which might be a bug on the publishing side but I unfortunately don't have the installations any more and can't debug this right now however those device keys keep showing under *Other devices* in Account Details even after hitting 'Clear devices'.

body:
I skimmed through the code and it appears that according to XmppAxolotlMessage OMEMO is using AES-128-GMC. GMC mode is an AEAD and is self-authenticating so wouldn't this mean that OMEMO is not deniable because it can't be spoofed even without an HMAC ?

Perhaps I'm misunderstanding the flow of the crypto or something. 

Another point to note is that is if this the case deniability (of say OTR) does not apply as much today because of mandated TLS use by XMPP operators. GMC mode is also one of the latest, fastest and most secure modes of AES operation.
title: OMEMO deniability

I think I found a bug. I don't know exactly if it is a bug or not; but the following steps will reproduce it at least in my mobile (Sony Xperia z3 Android 5.1.1).

1. Clear all chat conversations. (You should be in contacts list).
2. Open Conversation App.
3. Press Home button (Not back button) to go to the desktop.
4. Open Conversation App again.
5. Press Home button again.
6. Repeat steps 1, 2 few more times.
7. Open Conversation App again.
8. Now press back button to close the app (No Home button this time).

Everytime you press back button, a new instance of the app will pop up. The total number of instances will be the number of times you have opened through steps 1 and 2 plus the 7th one.

body:
As described in Issue https://github.com/siacs/Conversations/issues/1336 an IOException occurs if the content-length field is not present in HTTP-Response.

According to the RFC this field is not MUST:
http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.13
>Applications SHOULD use this field to indicate the transfer-length of the message-body, unless this is prohibited by the rules in section 4.4.
title: IOException if content-length is not present

body:
Hi,

when i sent an image to an android device with version 4.2.x i get an exception.

i found this 'Socket implements Closeable only since API level 19 (kitkat)'
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21353474/android-exception-using-closeable-interface-with-socket

quik fix:

```
@@ -218,7 +218,12 @@ public class JingleSocks5Transport extends JingleTransport {
        public void disconnect() {
                FileBackend.close(inputStream);
                FileBackend.close(outputStream);
-               FileBackend.close(socket);
+               // Socket implements Closeable only since API level 19
+               // https://code.google.com/p/android/issues/detail?id=62909
+               try {
+                       socket.close();
+               } catch (IOException e) {
+               }
        }

        public boolean isEstablished() {
```
Exception:
```
java.lang.IncompatibleClassChangeError: interface not implemented
    at eu.siacs.conversations.persistance.FileBackend.close(FileBackend.java:555)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.jingle.JingleSocks5Transport.disconnect(JingleSocks5Transport.java:221)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.jingle.JingleConnection.disconnectSocks5Connections(JingleConnection.java:881)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.jingle.JingleConnection.receiveSuccess(JingleConnection.java:781)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.jingle.JingleConnection.deliverPacket(JingleConnection.java:180)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.jingle.JingleConnectionManager.deliverPacket(JingleConnectionManager.java:48)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.services.XmppConnectionService$3.onJinglePacketReceived(XmppConnectionService.java:144)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.XmppConnection.processIq(XmppConnection.java:489)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.XmppConnection.processStream(XmppConnection.java:385)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.XmppConnection.processStream(XmppConnection.java:300)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.XmppConnection.switchOverToTls(XmppConnection.java:575)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.XmppConnection.processStream(XmppConnection.java:286)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.XmppConnection.connect(XmppConnection.java:226)
    at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.XmppConnection.run(XmppConnection.java:273)
    at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:856)
```

body:
As of commit 53ce5d223ea15b748c268d0e77c81d93d97706b0 Conversations fails to connect for me.

When it attempts resource binding it appears that the session initialization IQ is sent, eg.

```xml
<iq id="13dp1hlji3" type="set"><session xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:xmpp-session"/></iq>
```

but immediately afterwards `clearIQCallbacks()` runs again for some reason which clears session initialization IQ callback (replacing its result with an error), so session resumption fails and the connection is disconnected.

If you then disable the account, the `disconnect()` method is called, and the loop:

```java
while (!tagWriter.finished()) {
    Log.d(Config.LOGTAG, "not yet finished");
    Thread.sleep(100);
}
```

ends up running infinitely because the async tag writer is no longer running and the output queue will never reach zero.
title: Conversations cannot connect and enters infinite loop waiting for output queue to clear

On every reconnect I get a notification that the subject was changed.
![screenshot_2015-07-23-12-11-55](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/715896/8858533/3ced1ee0-3178-11e5-8d77-9511f4631be7.png)

In pidgin I get two different related messages depending on if the subject change was recent during delay spam
```xml
<message from='s...@....uk/zeeZ' to='zeez@....uk/Pidgin' type='groupchat'>
	<subject>There is no topic</subject>
	<delay xmlns='urn:xmpp:delay' from='s...@....uk' stamp='2015-07-14T10:53:09Z'/>
	<x xmlns='jabber:x:delay' stamp='20150714T10:53:09'/>
</message>
```
or past history immediately after delay spam
```xml
<message from='s...@....uk' to='zeez@....uk/Pidgin' type='groupchat'>
	<subject>There is no topic</subject>
	<body>zeeZ has set the subject to: There is no topic</body>
</message>
```

If it's super recent I don't get the repeat message in Conversations, but it'll eventually start doing that again. Not sure if that's a bug, a feature request or a really weird server I'm dealing with.

body:
Adds a preference "Backup to SD card" to Expert Options > Other.
It writes the logs to SD card in cleartext using a pidgin-like folder structure. The logs use the format "(time) jid: message \n". Newlines within chat messages are distinguished by "\" escaping them.

A similar feature was discussed in #1252, but I decided to use an easily human readable format to not make the feature only usable for people familiar with databases.
title: Preference to backup logs to SD card

body:
`WORK IN PROGRESS - OPEN DISCUSSION`

Okay, I know this is a difficult topic and most of the changes are a matter of taste. I'm preparing this pull request (so **don't merge this in yet**) and I am willing to work on it as long as I still have got the feeling the changes have a good chance to make it into the final app.

![Example screenshot](http://i.imgur.com/a1iw3bU.png)

[Older example screenshot](http://i.imgur.com/BegsID1.png) (Composed of three screenshots)

What I tried to do was to improve the overall message layouts in a way that would emphasize incoming messages and provide the user with a much modern overall appearance - without changing the code too much. I also tried to equalize margins and paddings.
I made these changes because I - personally - couldn't stand the grey border and dull colors for much longer and I just had enough drive to make the changes by myself, because I believe that's the only way to achieve anything at all.
I have yet to check what happens to inline images.

- I am willing to *discuss* my changes.
- I am willing to work on *fixes* if needed.
- I am willing to *change* details.

Changes could also include settings that would control the "new look".

This is my first contribution to a foreign project ever and if I did anything wrong, I'm doing this to learn, too. I already learned *so much* and I would be glad to learn even more, so yay!

### Open tasks:
- [x] Create and post example screenshots
- [x] Fix issue with recycled views (message font color)
- [ ] Inline images are scaled/cropped weirdly
- [x] Full-width messages
- [x] Let profile images breathe
- [ ] Rethink error states
- [x] Black locks on incoming messages
- [x] Don't use alpha channel for message text colors
- [ ] Try to find a less saturated incoming (dynamic?) color
- [x] Fix incoming link colors
- [x] Make rounded corners half as big
- [x] Fix transparency on drop shadows (please be subtle)
title: Changed message bubble appearance

body:
Hello there,
I really like Conversations, its the best jabber app I ever found and I am using it since it version 0.2 :-)))
There are 2 little improvements, I would be happy to see in some release sooner or later:
1.) I dont want to be online with my smartphone all the time, so I deactivate the Wifi or mobile data many times a day. If I only hit the "Wifi off" button in the android settings however, the xmpp server seems to hope that I will return soon, and thus only after 10-20 minutes it will then return an error message to my friends, that the message could not be delivered. This is of course annoying to my friends, and partly this is of course also a server problem. To circumvent this problem I go to the accounts settings in conversations, and "temporarily deactivate" my xmpp connection before I hit the "WIFI off" button. Then the xmpp server shows me as offline to my friend and stores their messages for offline storage, and doesnt return an error. 

Unfortunately it is much too tiresome do so so every time, multiple times a day, so if I dont have time, I just quickly deactivate the WIFI without logging out of the server. Thus, it would be really great if conversations could hook in any connection change event handler and log out of the xmpp server automatically before switching of the wifi device, when I hit the "wifi off" button. 

Maybe this can be achieved by registering some "android account" for conversations, like xabber did.
title: automatically logout from server when going offline

Conversations Version: 1.4.3 - From F-Droid.

*adb -d logcat -C -v time -s conversations*
```
06-03 10:29:00.410 D/conversations( 4965): osaka@matrix.ac: connecting
06-03 10:29:00.413 D/conversations( 4965): using dns server: *.*.14.13 to look up matrix.ac
06-03 10:29:00.433 D/conversations( 4965): using dns server: *.*.6.66 to look up matrix.ac
06-03 10:29:00.450 D/conversations( 4965): using dns server: 8.8.8.8 to look up matrix.ac
06-03 10:29:05.449 D/conversations( 4965): osaka@matrix.ac: unhandled exception in DNS resolver
```

*DNS Zone*
```
matrix.ac. 1800 IN A 178.62.58.156
xmpp.matrix.ac. 1800 IN A 178.62.58.156
_xmpp-client._tcp.matrix.ac. 1800 IN SRV 0 5 5222 xmpp.matrix.ac.
_xmpp-client._tcp.matrix.ac. 1800 IN SRV 0 10 443 xmpp.matrix.ac.
_xmpp-server._tcp.matrix.ac. 1800 IN SRV 0 5 5269 xmpp.matrix.ac.
_xmpp-server._tcp.conference.matrix.ac. 1800 IN SRV 0 5 5269 xmpp.matrix.ac.
```

*Note*: We know this is not the correct setup, and have configured the DNS to use priorities instead of weights for finding an alternative connection.
title: Unhandled exception on SRV DNS using weights.

body:
I had my father in law change from Xabber to Conversation. He really likes it, but he misses one feature. In Xabber it is supposedly possible to swipe between open conversations. He'd like to have such a feature to. It is really much like you can already swipe from the list of all open conversations to the last active one. I created a mock of the feature, hoping that it makes it easier to understand:
![swipe_across_conversations_mockup](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1614558/7796003/f8dd5790-02da-11e5-80ea-290272ef5d1a.png)

So the idea is, that out of an active conversation you'd swipe from right to left over the conversation history, to move on the the last active conversation and so on. Once you are on the end you cannot swipe anymore. You can also swipe from left to right, to get back to the more recent conversation. Once you are at the most recent one and swipe from left to right, you will swipe in the conversation list (same as it is implemented right now). Once you type into one of the conversations or receive a message, this conversation fragment is always put first in the list.

This way you'd always know to swipe left to right, in order to get to the more recent conversation or chat events, and the other way around. We might think about an indicator, giving you some topological view of the conversation fragments, especially when they move around in the background due to received messages.

What do you guys think? Too complicated or a missing feature?
title: Feature: Swipe across open conversations

body:
One example:

I send/receive the link to the internationalized domain [はじめよう.みんな](http://はじめよう.みんな) (Punycode: [xn--p8j9a0d9c9a.xn--q9jyb4c](http://xn--p8j9a0d9c9a.xn--q9jyb4c)) in a message.

The hyperlink will result in the following:

1. For はじめよう.みんな: No clickable hyperlink.
2. For xn--p8j9a0d9c9a.xn--q9jyb4c: [``xn--p8j9a0d9c9a.xn``](http://xn--p8j9a0d9c9a.xn)``--q9jyb4c``

resulting in the issue that the link cannot be clicked at all. The only possibility is to copy the entire message, strip the surrounding text and paste it into the web browser. Naturally, this is extremely cumbersome on smartphones.

An implementation solution would be to:

1. Recognize the Punycode pattern in Domains. Everything like foo.xn--bar should be recognized as a valid URL. Also keep in mind that URLs like xn--p8j9a0d9c9a.xn--q9jyb4c/%E3%83%96... are possible.
2. For URLs in Unicode (and to recognize other TLDs), the Public Suffix List can be used: https://publicsuffix.org/list/.

Well, this would certainly be a nice feature :)
title: Hyperlink of internalionalised TLDs does not work

body:
Currently, "disable all accounts" is a "global overwriter", it simply sets all the accounts to the "temporarily disable" state. Consequently, it cannot be reversed. You cannot re-enable only the accounts that were enabled before clicking that button.

I propose a simple change: "disable all accounts" should be a global switch, which does not modify the individual accounts' state. Instead, in overrides those states and makes all accounts log off. When it's clicked again, the individual accounts' online/offline states are respected again and only the accounts that were previously online re-connect.
title: Make "Disable all accounts" a global switch

body:
So having read the bugtracker, there are a number of things that keep popping over and over. Mainly:

 * No presence support (great exposition by @Yajo on #236)
 * No status indication (note the last comment by @devurandom on #440)
 * No support for full set of configuration options (e.g., explicit setting of hostname / port, with a fantastic summary by @SafwatHalaby on #962, there are also other issues concerning TLS use, etc.)
 * Multiple support requests on the bugtracker, and subsequent complaints (including my own at #1196)

Quickly put, the problem is not so much the lack of those features but the reason they are lacking: which is that the development lead waves them away because, I paraphrase, "they don't fit with *the vision*".

That's cool, but I respectfully suggest that the above is not a viable long-term attitude, and not one that's going to go down well with employers looking at a candidate's Github.

As for me, I tried this application. It has some good things: it supports carbon copies and MOM, and feels responsive (unlike Xabber 2.0, sadly). Sadly, given the lack of leadership and project management skills shown here by the main developer, there is no way I would be relying on this application in the long term. It has now been uninstalled.
title: Appalling Usability

body:
When I connect to my chat server I get a warning:  "Accept Mismatching Server Name? Server could not authenticate as "josefsson.org".  The certificate is only valid for: [2] chat.sjd.se".  My JID is simon@josefsson.org and through SRV records my chat server is chat.sjd.se.

However, the certificate presented by my server contains the PKIX SRV-ID identifier type as described in RFC 6120 section 13.7.1.2.1: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6120#section-13.7.1.2.1 Thus I believe it should be able to read out from the certificate the 1.3.6.1.5.5.7.8.7 extension which says "_xmpp-client.josefsson.org" and use that to validate the use for "josefsson.org".

Let me know if I'm missing something.  Some more info about my PKIX certificate setup is available here: http://blog.josefsson.org/2015/05/12/certificates-for-xmpp-jabber/
title: Validate Subject Alternative Names in Certificates

body:
Hi,

Thanks in advance for reading this. Please let me know if I can supply additional information and I'll be happy to do so.

## Setup

* Client: Conversations 1.3.1
* Server: Prosody 0.10 nightly (latest)

## Background

Last September one of the developers for Prosody (Kim "Zash" Alvefur ) released a small module called "mod_proxy65_whitelist". This module successfully forced Conversations to use the file transfer proxy which Prosody provides instead of trying to use direct transfers (which fail due to firewalls). 

File transfer speeds went from very slow (what they are now) to near instantaneous. It was amazing. Sometime in recent months file transfers fell back to old speeds. At best they take a full minute (which is mostly acceptable, but still slow), but 3-10 minutes for a sub 30 KB file is not uncommon now.

I assumed the problem was the module itself, so I reported the issue to the Prosody Users list to see if others were affected. Kim was the only one to reply.

Kim suggested:

* Fixing firewalls
* Asking the Conversation developers about improving proxy selection code

The box hosting the Prosody server has the port open to world, so that end should be fine. I of course can't account for networks between clients, which is why I'd like to force them to use the server for all file transfers so they're more reliable. 

## Goal

I'd like to restrict Conversations to using only the file transfer proxy that Prosody provides. 

It appears that we have to wait for client-to-client transfers to time out and fall back to client-to-server transfers to begin, so I'd rather cut out the wait time and just have the clients go directly to the server to start with.

Accomplishing this server-side would be preferable because all clients would be affected (we run a private XMPP server with all clients aware of the particulars of the setup), but a client-side setting would be helpful.

## References

* [Is the proxy65_whitelist module compatible with recent 0.10 nightly builds?](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/prosody-users/XYSiYiZdnp0)
* [Help with mod_proxy65](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/prosody-users/mod_proxy65_whitelist/prosody-users/Mzib2u2FOfw/3pEBVuwBhiEJ)
* [BIND zonefile with proxy65 record](http://www.wensley.org.uk/xmpp/zonefile)
  * I can't find other examples, so I assume the specific zone entry isn't valid
title: Request: Add option to restrict file transfers to SOCKS5 Bytestream (mod_proxy65) proxy

body:
With old OpenKeychain, messages were always encrypted to self, thus you could read your own messages on another device when using carbon copy.
With OpenKeychain 3.2 , that does not work anymore as it looks as if the sender is not automatically added to the encryption recipients.

Please ensure that the message is also encrypted to the sender's key.
title: OpenPGP Messages not encrypted to self after OpenKeychain update

body:
Hello everyone, 


We're experiencing an issue with Conversations v1.3.1 'paired' with Ejabberd v15.03. 

Namely, one of the users attempts sending a file (image) to me, and once the file transfer reaches 99% and is about to complete, 
I get "The file has been deleted" message. We've tried numerous times 5+ today and it failed every time with this same message. 
If I send him an image >3x larger (750KB), they receive it no problems whatsoever.

I've enabled the debug logging level, and you can find the log excerpt (just prior the file transfer ends, and after it ended) here: https://gist.github.com/milosb/2fd555b3c439ac6a8010

Hope it's not too modest excerpt - but with the debugging level I could attach several megs.

On both ends, Conversations client is configured with OTR encryption, and max file size to accept is set to 10MB.
Ejabberd has stanza size set to 131Kb, and traffic shaper rule is now 'fast' for everyone, even though it used to be 'normal'. There are <10 users on the server, 
and far from it there's a lot of traffic running through the server.
The OS Ejabberd is running on is CentOS 6.6 64bit.


Any ideas would be greatly appreciated. 


Thanks,
Milos.
title: File transfer reaches 99% and report "The file has been deleted"

body:
Hi there -

I've been using Conversations as my XMPP client, and I really like it.

I have ejabberd deployed at work, and I'll be logged in on my workstation (via Adium) along with Conversations.

Nearly all my coworkers strictly use XMPP from their workstations (never from home, a phone, etc), and they wind up treating an "available" status as "in the office" - but oftentimes I'm running around and not at my desk.

My workstation is setup to idle after a few minutes, and set my status to away - but I'll still show as available. I'll also forget to temporarily disable my account when leaving for the day and get messages from people.

I still want the client on my phone, since it's really handy to be able to message other sysadmins while I'm running around fixing this or that, but I'd prefer to let the workstation's status "win", or just not show as available at all if my phone is the only connected resource.

Is there anyway to accomplish that?
title: Invisibilty/low-priority?

[XEP-0357](http://www.xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0357.html) defines semantics for a XMPP server to inform its users of new messages, so their XMPP clients can connect and receive the data.

This seems very useful to allow Conversations to reconnect automatically. (Currently it often gets stuck, and displays a disconnected notification with a "try again" button, that I have to tap manually. I assume there is some OS inherent issue that prevents Conversations from automatically reconnecting? Maybe receiving a GSM message would "unstuck" it, and allow it to revive its background service to reconnect.)
title: XEP-0357 (Push Notifications) support

In window of chatting with buddy in menu after click "invite contact" and selecting contact created new MUC with random name. "Conversations" app automatically opening this MUC-room. That looks good. But:
1. ejabberd sees this room is empty
2. Contact after answer to invitation cannot connect to room because this MUC-room was not been created.

For successfully invitation:
1. Open other client with same JID (Gajim in my case).
2. Invite third contact to chat with Conversations.
3.  In Gajim I have invitation to my JID to new room. Accept it.
3.1. Connecting to new room as owner (in Gajim)
3.2 In Conversations nothing changes
4. After that other recipients can accept invitation and connect to new MUC-room. 

I assume that I have not properly configured the XMPP server Ejabberd(version 15.03).
It seems to me that this method of invitation is not an implementation of [XEP-0045/continue](http://xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0045.html#continue).

This is my muc config:

```yaml
  mod_muc: 
    access: muc
    access_create: muc
    access_persistent: muc
    access_admin: muc_admin
    history_size: 50
    max_users: 500
    default_room_options:

      allow_private_messages: false
      allow_user_invites: true
      logging: true
      members_by_default: true

      public: true
      public_list: false
```

Can anyone show me correctly ejabberd configuration for MUC?

body:
1.) I noticed that FB messenger has two stage "tick" indicator. I only speculate about its meaning, but it brought me to idea about this useful feature: let's show another indicator (e.g. smaller or inverted color tick) when the message is successfully delivered from my client to the server and then another indicator when the other client confirms reception like it is done now.

This would make debugging problems with undelivered messages much easier.

Undelivered messages can be fault of either client or server and most of the time it is a nightmare to determine which one is responsible. Readouts of the "delivered to server indicator" would make problem reports from normal users much easier to interpret.

2.) The message delivery can be very unreliable under certain conditions (some XMPP server software or configuration in conjunction with clients that are constantly on and off the network, such as smartphones in moving car or metro).

Right now the user can see that some of the messages were not delivered most of the time, but even that is not very clear in some situations: when two messages sent shortly after each other, they are merged into one block. In this case only one tick is displayed for both messages. This is a problem, because it can obscure the fact that the first message was missed and create confusion in the conversation.

Delivery indicators should be displayed for every message separately.
title: Feature request: indicator when messages are delivered to server and indicator for every message separately

body:
- Fix session handling on contact status change: Do not reset
  potentially active sessions; check peer's OTR-resource on disconnect
- use no-permanent-store hint instead of no-store to ensure
  finished-messages are delivered to offline/disconnected clients
- add no-permanent-store to ask compliant servers not to archive
  OTR messages

-
Further notes:
- If a contact is connected with several clients and disconnects with the OTR enabled client, that client will sometimes be listed in the resource dialog when I try to directly start a new OTR session. Haven't yet checked why and when this is the case, though.
- The Padlock symbol in the ActionBar is currently not updated on reception of an OTR finished message. Can we safely change line 375 in ConversationActivity from
`if this.getSelectedConversation().getLatestMessage().getEncryption() != [...]`to `if (this.getSelectedConversation().getNextEncryption(false) != [...]` to always reflect the mode for the next message or could this cause unwanted side effects (e.g., for PGP)?
- I think the switch from OTR to plaintext when the peer sent a finished message should be highlighted - when force encryption is not active it's sometimes hard to spot that the OTR session has been closed. What do you think about another SnackBar for this case?

After digging through most of the OTR-related code I think it'd be worth to consider maintaining sessions as long as possible - that is, only end sessions when the user logs out. This seems to be the approach ChatSecure and Xabber use and they do quite reliably so. This could massively decrease the message-overhead caused by KE messages and might also reduce code complexity to a certain degree.
title: OTR: Fix onContactStatusChanged & dont archive OTR

body:
From #1121 , it was concluded that image links are, in fact, automatically downloaded by Conversations if they end in one of a set of known extensions. Allegedly, a fiel size limit is checked before the file is downloaded.

The latter does not help in any way, as the issue is of a different kind. Automatically sending an HTTP request to a random host upon receiving a message is a security flaw as it leaks private data to the HTTP server, e.g. if someone in a MUC sends an iamge link, at least a HEAD request is made to find out the file size, but that is enough to produce a connection to a foreign host which might be controlled by an attacker. The leaked data is more or less restricted to the client IP address, but especially on mobile networks, this is enough to retrieve rough location information as well.

The "feature" is enabled by default with the "Accept files smaller than …" option. File transfer and downloading image links should be split in two here, and downloading links should be disabled by default.

Opting out of automatic downloading of HTTP content is also a MUST in XEP-0071, which is not explicitly applicable here as it concerns XHTML-IM rather than links in plaintext messages, but I do not see any difference there: http://xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0071.html#security
title: [SECURITY] URLs pointing to image files are automatically downloaded

body:
When sending two links in one message separated only by a space, only the first picture is downloaded. This happens also, if the message ends with e.g. "/xyz.png".
Messages for reproducing:
`http://upload.mitsu-freunde-bw.de/uploads/2015/01/i15bgalni.jpg http://upload.mitsu-freunde-bw.de/uploads/2015/03/i27b1zd0m.png`
and
`http://upload.mitsu-freunde-bw.de/uploads/2015/03/i27b1zd0m.png here a some text which will not be shown, cause the image will be downloaded instead /abc.png`

The bug is caused by Message.bodyContainsDownloadable()

I've made a patch which first checks for blanks in the message (normally this should be %20 in an url) and also should speed up the check for an url.

Here the a Link to the patch: http://www.thehappy.de/~lookshe/pub/0001-better-and-perhaps-faster-way-for-checking-if-a-mess.patch
title: Bug in automatic download of image links

body:
Currently, conversations sends all file transfers in parallel, the files often do not arrive at the order they were sent. This has two drawbacks:
- It can make some conversations awkward, when the content of the files (e.g. images) is being discussed.
- Since network speed is limited, parallel transfer means that all files are sent slower. The receiver has to wait extra time to see the first file.

Sending files sequentially has its own disadvantage: Since in XMPP, initiating the transfer takes time, overall the files will take longer to arrive. But I think that maintaining the flow of the conversation is more important than sending speed.

*"Me: Awesome tower, isn't it?
Her: It's a cat o.O
Me: Oh, that one hasn't arrived yet, hold on..."*
title: Sending files sequentially rather than in parallel

body:
When one sends a file to a contact who appears online, but is in fact offline and is yet to timeout, the following scenario always follows:

- Conversations is -rightfully- unable to tell that the contact is not really online, so it offers them the file, an "offering" message appears below the file on the sender's device.
- Since the contact is not really there, the "offering" message remains as long as the contact is marked online by the server.
- Once the server decides to timeout the contact, Conversations realizes that the file offer was in vain and the "offering" message turns into "delivery failed".
- Since the contact is now officially offline and the delivery failed, the file will never arrive, unless the sender long-touches the file and selects "resend", in that case, the "delivery failed" message is transformed into "waiting".
- When the contact is back online, "waiting" becomes "offering", now this is a genuine file transfer, and the file is transfered successfully. (Unless the contact gets online only very briefly, in that case, the scenario repeats itself).

Since Conversations works on mobile, and mobile is unreliable, this scenario happens quite often, when a contact's connection is really bad, "delivery failed" can appear several times in a row and the user must click re-send numerous times. The average user is expecting a Whatsapp-like "send-and-forget", something which Conversations has impressively achieved with text messages. But due to this issue, the user has no guarantee of delivery when it comes to files.

There are two things that can be improved here:
- When the receiver disconnects while the sender's Conversations is in the "offering" state, the new state should automatically become "waiting", it makes no sense to change the state into "delivery failed" and force the user to manually re-send the file.
- The "Offering" state should be internal. From the user's perspective, the difference between "waiting" and "offering" is vague and confusing, this is especially true considering the fact that Conversations' design departs away from the Presence feature. Whether Conversations is internally "waiting" or "offering", the user should only see "waiting".

Note that I am not suggesting that Conversations should always automatically re-send the file when delivery fails, there are numerous cases where it makes sense to not re-send. I am suggesting that Conversations should automatically re-send *only* in the scenario mentioned above (Receiver disconnects while sender is in the "offering" state).
title: Fix proposal: Sending files when peer is practically offline, but not yet timed out

We are two people who have the same version of Conversations 1.2.0 on their phone (via F-droid).
We both have "force encryption" setting enabled in the expert options and the encryption set to OTR (we are both mutually verified).
We both have account on the same Prosody server.
We use the same conversation to send messages between us (i.e. we don't tear the conversation down and start a new one when we stop chatting for some time).

When we don't send any messages in the conversation for some time (hours) and then we resume chatting, the first message sent by whoever wants to continue the chat is undelivered (the other person doesn't get it and it is not marked as delivered). Second and next message continue the chat normally. This behaviour is easily reproducible for us.
title: First message after longer pause in running conversation is not delivered

I'd really like to see the '>' send-message button with the padlock overlay when OTR is enabled, as with other clients (TextSecure, ChatSecure).
I want to know at a glance that I'm sending messages securely or not without having to enter drop-down menus, and I think the padlock overlay on the send button is an excellent mechanism.

I think there's room for a colour distinction too. TextSecure uses green for plaintext, and blue for encrypted. It is also possible to distinguish whether messages in the chat history were sent plaintext or encrypted by the colour. Reaching consensus on these sorts of visual-language would be a good move across the board moving forward.
title: Show padlock overlay on send-message button when encryption is enabled

[XEP-0146](http://xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0146.html) documents a protocol for remotely changing status using [XEP-0050](http://xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0050.html).

While *ordinarily* there would be little use for this, I would like to be able to automatically set my Conversations resource's status remotely, using a bot. This bot would update my status text based on information about how active I currently am, on my location, etc. 

Using a bot for this would allow me to decouple updating status from the need to build custom Conversations: the statuses and the triggers would be based on my personal circumstances anyway: am I within this specific geofence? is it midnight wherever I currently am? etc.
title: Feature request: Status text change via XEP-0050

body:
When I'm available, XMPP clients of choice generally set `priority` attribute of the `<presence>` to 15. (This is my arbitrary choice.)

When I'm busy, I set it to 2. (Again, purely arbitrary.)

When I'm away, it goes down to 0.

In this manner, I'd like to use `priority` to make other clients not buzz me when I happen to be using the phone, and not using the other clients. Vice versa, I'd like Conversations to buzz me only when its priority is the same as the maximum priority (the default behavior in XMPP when sending to pure JID). 

I understand that this may not be the 'mobile-first' behavior expected by most users these days, which is why I'd be perfectly happy seeing it shoved under expert options.

(Unless Conversations wants to expose manually setting `show` attribute, I assume this depends on issue #1065.)
title: Feature request: Automatically changing priority (and obeying it)

body:
When passing the Choose Contact Activity a boolean called "multiple"
set to true, it now allows the user to select multiple contacts. Long
pressing a contact enters multiple selection mode and the selection is
confirmed using a button in the CAB. The Activity returns whether or not
multiple contacts were selected using the same boolean. If multiple
contacts were selected, an array of JID strings called "contacts" is
returned. The Choose Contact Activity now also honors "filter_contacts",
an array of strings containing JIDs that should not be displayed in
the picker.

The invite to conference dialog now uses this feature to enable inviting
multiple contacts at once. Additionally, Invite Contact uses
"filter_contacts" to only display contacts that are not yet
participating in the conversation
title: Added multiple select to Choose Contact Activity (squashed)

body:
When publishing the metadata for an avatar that was cached, Conversations currently specifies an image size of zero (`bytes='0'`).  This happens because `avatar.size` [isn't][1] [set][2] for cached avatars.  Not sure about the best place to do that (e.g., just setting `avatar.size = file.length()` in [`isAvatarCached()`][3] would work as well).  Either way, this commit should at least show the issue.  (Note that most of the diff is just indentation change.)

[1]: https://github.com/siacs/Conversations/blob/4aab45533ac8a32be2fe66b266b845aed02acf1b/src/main/java/eu/siacs/conversations/persistance/FileBackend.java#L322
[2]: https://github.com/siacs/Conversations/blob/4aab45533ac8a32be2fe66b266b845aed02acf1b/src/main/java/eu/siacs/conversations/persistance/FileBackend.java#L337
[3]: https://github.com/siacs/Conversations/blob/4aab45533ac8a32be2fe66b266b845aed02acf1b/src/main/java/eu/siacs/conversations/persistance/FileBackend.java#L316

body:
Implemented a new feature that lets users change notification settings on a per-conference basis: "Default (global)" is the same option as before, but now users may also choose "notify on all messages", "no notifications", "notify when my username is mentioned" and a completely new option "notify when a keyword is mentioned".
The options can be set in the ConferenceDetailsActivity, including editing the keyword list there. The keyword input field is auto-completed with keywords already set in other conferences.
This can also be seen as a fix for #629 and #735; it is also now possible to permanently disable notifications for a conference without triggering the snackbar.

The other commit fixes a small issue with the quickEdit dialogue, in which the keyboard is still displayed on-screen even after an input was validated or cancelled, leading to a suboptimal UX.
title: Per-conference notification options; incl. a new configurable keyword notification method

body:
With #959 all ciphers of the platform were enabled, but this also
includes several suites that are considered as very weak, even down to
NULL- and anon-ciphers which disable completely disable encryption
and/or authentication. Especially the anon-ciphers could be easily used
for a mitm-attack.

To remove all weak ciphers a blacklist with patterns of cipher-names was
added to Config.java. The blacklist is based on the "mandatory discards"
that Mozilla suggests to not use for TLS-servers because they are weak
or known to be broken.
https://wiki.mozilla.org/Security/Server_Side_TLS#Mandatory_discards
title: disable all really weak cipher suites

body:
In rare cases an unreadable OTR message is received. Conversations will ignore such a message without informing the user. As far as I can tell, the sender is not informed about the failure either.

As stated at https://otr.cypherpunks.ca/Protocol-v3-4.0.0.html, right at the bottom of the page:

Receiving a Data Message
If msgstate is MSGSTATE_ENCRYPTED:
    Verify the information (MAC, keyids, ctr value, etc.) in the message.
    If the verification succeeds:
[...]
    Otherwise, inform the user that an unreadable encrypted message was received, and reply with an Error Message. 

I was not able to reproduce this issue when using two Conversations clients, however, if one party uses Chatsecure for example, you can provoke unreadable messages like so:
1.) Start OTR session
2.) Disconnect Chatsecure without logging off by enabling airplane mode for example (logout will destroy OTR session, but temporary disconnects dont)
3.) Wait until Conversations is notified about Chatsecure being offline (i.e., after stream management timeout)
4.) At this point Conversations discards the OTR session. Now connect Chatsecure again and send a message to Conversations. Logcat gives an "unreadable message received", but neither the user nor Chatsecure is informed about this event

From my POV Conversations is rigth to destroy OTR sessions as soon as one party is offline. Nonetheless, it would be great to inform the user and sender about the unreadable message. Especiallly so since temporary disconnects happen quite frequently in a mobile environment.
title: Let the user know when an unreadable OTR message was received

body:
I am having trouble connecting to a jabberd2 (2.2.17) server running on Debian / LMDE. Conversations fails to connect several times until it finally (not really...) succeeds, and the c2s.log shows these messages:

Fri Mar  6 00:00:16 2015 [notice] [11] [2001:000:0000:303:f164:65b9:e8f7:f6d6, port=54101] connect
Fri Mar  6 00:00:18 2015 [notice] [11] PLAIN authentication succeeded: rsenger@abc-def.net 2001:000:0000:303:f164:65b9:e8f7:f6d6:54101 TLS
Fri Mar  6 00:00:18 2015 [notice] [11] bound: jid=rsenger@abc-def.net/gt-i8190
Fri Mar  6 00:00:18 2015 [notice] [11] packet sent before session start, closing stream
Fri Mar  6 00:00:18 2015 [notice] [11] [2001:000:0000:303:f164:65b9:e8f7:f6d6, port=54101] disconnect jid=rsenger@abc-def.net/gt-i8190, packets: 2
Fri Mar  6 00:00:18 2015 [notice] session 11 does not exist; telling sm to close

(ip address and domain name altered for security reasons)

This repeats several times, until the connection succeeds. After a short time, the connection is lost again, and the above behaviour shows up again until the connection is reestablished. After this happens, the peer client (Pidgin on Linux) complains that there are multiple sessions for the Conversations user. Every time Conversations reconnects, a new session appears, after 15 minutes or so up to eight. Most messages sent from Pidgin to Conversations get lost.

I googled "packet sent before session start, closing stream" error message, and found some older threads saying that this is caused by a client side protocol violation, which in at least one case was fixed in newer client version.

I do not have any problems connecting to this server with Pidgin/Linux, Pidgin/Windows, OS X and Xabber clients.

I can offer help for debugging is desired,
title: Trouble connecting to jabberd2 server

body:
***Note to Devs:*** This is not yet another “please implement custom IP/port/hostname” issue, please do not close without consideration. I have read the [relevant part in the faqs](https://github.com/siacs/Conversations#where-can-i-set-up-a-custom-hostname--port), and I have read the countless closed issues regarding the subject. -which are listed below-

The purpose of this issue is to:
- Consolidate all the closed issues into a single, thorough post. (Which could be linked to from the FAQ in the future)
- Hopefully end the endless stream of repetitive requests by providing a definitive, detailed answer.
- Attempt to convince the developers that SRV records are not always the right solution, and that an alternative is needed. I am more than open to be proven wrong.


For those who have no idea what I'm talking about, please read the preface / background.

# Preface / Background
Ever since the inception of Conversations, the same feature request had been popping again and again: Some people have their own custom servers, often without a proper DNS address, and often on a non-standard port. They want to be able to connect to them. Other clients such as Xabber provide those users the ability to specify a custom IP address / port to connect to. However, Conversations does not provide this in the UI. Those people cannot connect to their servers unless they setup SRV records.

This request popped up numerous times:
#978 #960 #942 #917 #911 #861 #935 #689 #583 #541 #482 #106

## The current solution
The current solution is setting up SRV records.
Also, there's a non official patch by @kevindelaney which allows this, it can be found here: https://github.com/siacs/Conversations/pull/1003

There are also some exotic, alternative hacky solutions such as modifying Android's `/etc/hosts`.

## The proposed solution
The main solution that was proposed in all the closed issues is identical: Add a "custom host/port" field in the UI, just like Xabber. The developers were not too keen about this idea, implying that this is not necessary, and that a proper setup should include SRV records and would not really require this.


# Disadvantages of SRV's
In this section, I list the shortcomings of SRV records and argue that they are not always the right solution, and that in fact we do need a "custom host/port" option in Conversations, I am more than open to be proven wrong. Also, if I missed a disadvantage, please tell me about it and it will be added.

- Not everyone has purchased a domain name. This is especially true for small private servers.
- For those who haven't purchased and domain name, setting up SRV records requires some custom DNS server witchcraft, which is much more complex than just typing a custom host/port in Conversations and is not always feasible.
- On many home XMPP servers, this solution alone is not viable due to NAT loopback issues. e.g. I can connect to myHomeXmppServer.example.com from the outside world (WAN), but not from my own house (LAN), because the DNS resolution returns my external IP. 
- People who setup external ports that map to different internal ports cannot use the server from the LAN side. (Unless conversation provides them a custom host/port option)

# Disadvantages of a "custom host/port"
This section has arguments against adding a "custom host/port" field into the Conversations UI. If I missed a disadvantage, please tell me about it, and it will be added.

- Most use cases break Jabber's federation. 

- If not correctly designed, UX could suffer from menu clutter and might confuse non tech-savvy users. this is resolvable via proper UI design.
title: Settling the "custom port/IP/hostname" issue once and for all

body:
In this scenario:

1. Server supports carbon copies
2. Pidgin, which does not support them, with OTR enabled and ongoing conversation
3. `Conversations` enabled

`Conversations` would receive undecipherable OTR messages for every message sent or received via Pidgin.

If I understand correctly, CCs are disabled by default unless one of the clients requests them. So, I suppose this can be workarounded by adding an option to disable carbon copies in `Conversations`.
title: Carbon copies with OTR and another client

Hello all,

First of all, to the dev team, thanks for the app Conversations, it is the best XMPP app I tried so far. 

I have registered a virtual server and I'm running Openfire xmpp server on it on CentOS. Basicly, Conversations is working really well. File transfer works great, but if a client goes offline, I can't get the file to go to the proxy server.

I think I put all the basic settings right in Openfire about the file transfer proxy. In my domains DNS records I have proxy.domain.com pointing with an A record to my servers IP. I have no SRV records pointing to 5222 or 5223 port.

In Openfire I added a rule:

xmpp.proxy.externalip to my servers IP.

Openfire is supporting XEP-0065. 

This is all I know about it, does anybody have any advise on how to get it to work? 

Thank you very much,

/Johan

body:
@iNPUTmice and I had a few discussions in the conference about using material design icons; so I made a branch that uses them only for Android 5.0.

The icons which are set programatically are currently using a simple if statement that checks the API version; the "correct" way to do this would be to get the attribute resources as a typed array, extract the drawable ID, and recycle the array, but that doesn't necessarily work everywhere (it requires a context to get the resources), and this just feels lighter weight (even if it's potentially more error prone later as it requires manual updating if we were to change the icons again in another version).

Currently there are a lot of extraneous icons in this pull; those can be deleted easily enough after we get the sizes and what not narrowed down a bit.

I used grey600 for the one place I found that a grey icon was needed; it may be better to do as someone else suggested and use the black icon and then set the opacity to 80%.

Icons should probably also be renamed (I've got them all as `ic_action_something` right now, but they're not all action icons).

## TODO:

 - [x] Decide if sizes are correct
 - [x] Remove unused sizes
 - [x] ~~Add SVG version of icons~~ (will figure this out later; I might have dreamed that Android 5.0 supported SVGs natively)

## Examples:

![screenshot_2015-01-21-16-50-12](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/512573/5876234/b7f8434a-a2e3-11e4-9ed2-270d91b6d387.png)

Until message archive management become reality, chat history is stored only on clients. It would be nice to have simple option to export the full history to some parsable format (like JSON or SQLite database), so it can be easily converted and imported into other Jabber client or to future server-side message archive.

For example Gajim stores history in SQLite database, so import can be done using few SQL queries.

The export should be lossless and as simple as possible (from programmer's point of view). It can be hidden in somewhere in settings. Dump should be stored in file on SD card with timestamp in the filename, and file share menu may be presented to user when export is complete.
title: Chat log/history export

body:
For no apparent reason, Android 2.3 and up (~~I haven't checked if this changed at all on Android 5.0~~ Just checked, Android 5.0 uses terrible defaults as well) use insecure RC4/MD5 cipher suites by default (queue rogue intelligence agency payoff speculation).

Since we only support TLS (unless you turn on an advanced legacy setting), we should use our own cipher suite and prioritize ciphers with perfect forward secrecy. If legacy SSL is enabled, just use the defaults (since you have other problems to worry about and there was talk of removing it entirely in the 1.0 release).

The current list prioritizes AES128 over AES256, and SHA256 over SHA384 to save battery. It's possible that on slow devices without hardware support AES256 will be subject to timing attacks anyways which MAY be harder with AES128 as it will run a bit faster (I'm making that up off the top of my head; it's just a suspicion, take it with a grain of salt). Regardless, AES128 is probably secure for all intents and purposes.

I also added some non-[EC]DHE ciphers at the end for compatibility... I think this should cover most servers and Android versions (I glanced at a few popular servers on XMPP.net and they all have something in this list).

AES CBC mode is avoided in favor of GCM mode if possible.
title: Harden TLS cipher suites

A Issue i encounter quite often and which makes conversations very unreliable (almost useless) to me is conversation loosing the connection to the server and not issuing a reconnect while in the background:

* Phone/Conversations is idle for a prolonged time.
* At some point, server[own prosody instance] notices the connection is no longer available and hibernates the session
* Conversations won't notice that the connection is dead, no notification arrives
* In the moment you open Conversation (put it into foreground), Conversations notices its connection is dead and tries to reboot it - if i'm lucky its in my session hibernation timeout and everything is replayed, otherwise i might be lucky that the new message was offline stored.

I don't think its a phone/network issue:

Yesterday we decided to install a 2nd messenger on the same phone (xabber). Overnight my partners' conversations dropped connection - only xabber played a notification on the message this morning.


Catlog shows Conversations making a new connection in the instance it comes to foreground.

I'd like it if Conversations did not automatically download images linked in a chat. When fetching images remotely, not only do I access a third party webserver giving away IP address and such to the remote party as well as my ISP, but there have also been many cases of security holes in image libraries. Such vulnerabilities could quickly and easily be abused when discovered if peoples' XMPP clients gladly download anything anyone sends them.

I'd prefer that this was an opt-in preference, since the security and privacy implications of auto-downloading and parsing data from random sources can be pretty severe.
title: Option to disable (or preferrably opt-in) auto-download of HTTP/HTTPS images

Hello,

this might or might not be related to #811. I just saw Conversations being unable to connect again, while my laptop using Psi+ had no trouble connecting (and reconnecting when I forced the connection to close from the server) to my Prosody server. I saw it happen twice since upgrading to 0.10 now.

I restarted Prosody to ensure that the server had no issue with any cached data. Psi+ happily reconnected after a couple of seconds.
Watching the server log I did not see any connection attemps from Conversations, which just kept repeating the "Server nicht gefunden" (~ server not found) message

Both my laptop and the android device are connected through the same WLAN, so the routing should be exactly the same.
Not sure if Psi+ uses the SRV records to determine the actual server name, but this shouldn't really matter as my domain name and the SRV record point to the same IP both in IPv4 and IPv6:
example.com IN A 1.2.3.4
example.com IN AAAA 1:2:3:4:5::6
xmpp.example.com IN A 1.2.3.4
xmpp.example.com IN AAAA 1:2:3:4:5::6
_xmpp-client._tcp.example.com  18000 IN SRV     0 5 5222 xmpp.example.com

After disconnecting from the WLAN, Conversations was able to connect at once. Reenabling WLAN resulted in Conversations being able to connect through the WLAN as well.

I did not see any way to enabling logging somewhere or to get a better error message what exactly failed. Can you provide more detailed errors in Conversations?
title: Server not found WLAN issues

body:
Previous discussed in #45.

## Current work

- [x] Don't bother checking SRV records for `.onion` domains
- [x] ~~Use Tor for DNS requests~~ (not applicable since we're only doing .onion addresses for now)
- [x] Remove SOCKS config in favor of Tor only
- [x] Make sure `.onion` routing is working
- [x] Use Tor only for .onion addresses until SRV lookups are implemented in Tor's DNS
- [x] Don't error on certificate mismatch for `.onion`; instead, show the warning and let the user choose to pin the invalid cert
- [x] Add Tor support for HTTP connections
- [ ] Make sure HTTP connections aren't leaking DNS all over the floor
- [ ] Add Tor support for Jingle connections

## Possible future improvements

Possible future improvements:

- Add a check to see if Orbot is installed and/or started and display an appropriate error if "Always use Tor" is set or we're connecting to a Tor HS.
- When changing the Tor setting, bounce all non-HS accounts (HS accounts always use Tor).
- Detect Tor proxy and DNS ports instead of hard coding them (Orbot doesn't have an intent for this yet)
- Possibly ensure stream isolation when multiple accounts are in use? This may happen anyways; all the circuit building stuff has changed around since the last time I really dug into Tor in depth.
title: Tor support

- * or similiar. I tested with german locale.

body:
I'm still unsure how I feel about this as a solution (readability wise it's pretty terrible). Thoughts / code review to make sure I'm not leaving any holes open appreciated.

Converting the type to an enum didn't end up being necessary... I wanted some guarantee that you wouldn't get an invalid packet type originally, but I can't remember why. Left it anyways because it prevents developers from assigning invalid packet types inadvertantly in future.
title: Verify IQ responses

body:
Make `app_name` untranslatable (and remove it from translations)
Remove untraslatable string and fix escaping in NL translation
title: Several translation fixes

body: When I open a chat or reopen an existing chat after a while, the first message sent in that chat is not delivered. Starting with the second message all messages arrive as expected.
title: First message not delivered

body:
Just a few random typo fixes in the docs and one method name.

Also rewrap docs at 80 chars (which is what it looked like it was at in most places).
title: Fix spelling in the docs / a method

body:
Conversations build from last git show empty roster from my jabberd2 server. This is strange because when I first installed Conversations may be a week ago there was no such problem. But yesterday I remove app from my device and install it again with new build. And them roster was empty. Actually if I add new contact, this new contact is shown, but all old contacts are missing. 
If I revert to 96569700512e9618efa18eeb277665045678e16d and build app it shows roster normally. Then if I build again app with last git and re-install it on device without removing old version (just install over old version) it show roster.
title: Emptry roster

body:
I'm receiving crash reports for the following:
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.XmppConnection.switchOverToTls(XmppConnection.java:555)
	at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.XmppConnection.processStream(XmppConnection.java:263)
	at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.XmppConnection.connect(XmppConnection.java:219)
	at eu.siacs.conversations.xmpp.XmppConnection.run(XmppConnection.java:250)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:841)

Which corresponds to the lines:
554: if (socket == null) throw new IOException("socket was null");
555: SSLSocket sslSocket = (SSLSocket) factory.createSocket(socket, socket.getInetAddress().getHostAddress(), socket.getPort(), true);


So it seems to be either a problem resolving the IP to a host or getting the port number of the socket.
Not sure if this is related to https://github.com/siacs/Conversations/issues/811
title: Crash on TLS Connection

body: I would really like to gift Conversions to some of my friends. Unfortunately this is not possible in Google Play Store. On Amazon you can do this.
title: Add Conversations to Amazon App Store

body:
There seems to be a bug in the current Conversations release: After having connected successfully to my XMPP server "trashserver.net" the connections drops after a few minutes and I get an error "Server could not be found". I have checked the connection to the server with different Apps, but the connection is fine and DNS resolving is working perfectly. It's only Conversations having problems.

When i restart the App, the connection is fine again... until it suddenly drops again.

I'm not the only person who has this issue. I've heard of people who lose connection to openmailbox.org as well.
title: Connection to XMPP server drops

body:
Current head of development branch doesn't show server information if
blocking is disabled. This is due to slightly wrong logic on an if
statement. This patch ensures only the blocking option is disabled when
blocking is not supported by the server, and that the feature remains
available.
title: Show server info option when blocking is unavailable

body:
When a file or image transmission has status "waiting" (eg. send a file to a contact who is offline), the transfer can't be canceled via the long-press context menu.

I threw a quick patch together [here](https://github.com/SamWhited/Conversations/tree/sendfixes), but I don't really understand the file transfer code well enough yet and suspect this is the wrong way to go about it. May not be able to get back to this today, so I made the issue in case anyone else has time to fix it or wants to take a look.
title: Allow canceling of transmissions with status "waiting"

body:
Don't show menu on create account screen. Just noticed that I didn't hide the "show more info" menu item when creating a new account or when the account is offline.

Make sure the account gets the username correctly when it's a domain JID (See #806).
title: Misc minor bug fixes

body:
When trying to login with a domain name (empty user name) This crashes sasl with ejabberd.
Somehow the xml coming back isn't parseable. I'm not sure whether we are sending broken xml in the first place or ejabberd is sending broken xml back to us.

````
jabber.ccc.de/phone: Authenticating with SCRAM-SHA-1
jabber.ccc.de: Attr.value missing f. attribute (position:START_TAG <bad-format attribute='urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:xmpp-sasl'>@1:603 in java.io.InputStreamReader@429c57c0)
````

I cant reproduce this with gajim because gajim wont let me enter a domain jid... Don't have other clients installed right now. Gonna move this into a separate issue.
title: login in with just a domain jid breaks sasl auth with ejabberd

body: Removes the old REGEX based JID validator (the JID class does its own validation now).
title: Remove old JID validator

body:
Adding more supported XEPs to the list on the account details screen was discussed in #574. It was decided that a show more button would reduce clutter, but still allow people to get info about their server. Unfortunately, I forgot about it (and did something weird when rebasing from the looks of the issue) until just now.

If this is still of interest, I added a show more button, and added MaM and Blocking to the list (in the regular list and the show more list respectively).

I'm not sure that the button looks great; maybe a link would be better.

![screenshot_2014-12-22-14-46-50](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/512573/5530108/38501da0-89ea-11e4-828c-b684890cff30.png)
![screenshot_2014-12-22-14-46-45](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/512573/5530109/38524710-89ea-11e4-997e-98edd80de5cb.png)

(MAM string is different from the screenshots; it now reeds `MAM (History)`; a cue I took from `PEP (Avatars)`.
title: Server info

body:
During a discussion with @iNPUTmice a few days ago we talked about doing a small refactor of the `Iqparser` code. I've added that here, and also added a fix for #20. The logic is slightly different than it was before, but I couldn't see why stanzas should check if the from is null or not (null from = sent from server, which means the to will be null which means the response will go to the server). Correct me if I'm wrong.

Fixes #20
title: Refactor roster handling / IqParser code
Fix NPEs in blocking code

body: Fixes #260
title: Add ability to change password on server

body:
I am implementing [XEP-0191][xep0191] in [this branch](https://github.com/SamWhited/Conversations/tree/xep0191); this issue is to solicit feedback after a discussion about it in the conference room earlier. To sum up the discussion:

My initial thoughts on the interface were to make a dynamic tag called `blocked` for each blocked contact, and to add a `Blocked` or `Unblocked` button to the contact's long-press context menu, and to the menu in an open conversation with them. If dynamic tags weren't enabled, you would not be able to tell if the contact was blocked without opening up a conversation with them, which seemed inline with the policy on presence. However, you would be prevented from sending them messages.

A thought that just occured to me: We could use the conversation "pill" menu (not sure what this is called) to show that the contact is blocked when you open a conversation (the same menu that is used to show that a MUC room is silenced).

If the server reports a blocked user who is not actually on the roster, there would be no roster item added for that user. If a chat was opened with that user (eg. a spammer who's not on your roster messages you), you could still block them / unblock them from the conversation menu or the "pill" as described above.

Thoughts?

[xep0191]: http://xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0191.html
title: XEP-0191: Blocking command

body:
XMPP gives us a lot of control over conference rooms (MUCs). The access control is far more complex than what for example IRC has to offer. (Some might say it is over engineered)
Obviously it wouldn't be the Conversations way to expose all of that functionality to the end-user. However more advanced users might miss certain functionalities MUC has to offer and maybe even some regular users will end up liking some of the features if we implement them well enough (Make them easy enough to use.)
However for this to work we need to pick a subset of the MUC spec and pack that into a good user experience.

Now my question to the 'more advanced users' of Conversations. Which muc functionality do you need very often and would like to see in Conversations?

And if there are any 'regular users' reading this issue tracker? What are some conference features / options / controls you would like to have? You can use plain English to describe. You don't have to use IRC or MUC vocabulary.

To become a bit more specific my thoughts on that would be to provide a simple Private / Public switch which in the background would set membersonly=1, whois=anyone, public=0 or their reverse respectively.
On top of that it might be a good idea to ditch the entire role stuff in favor of only using affiliations. The background here is that roles are temporary and affiliations are not. (Thus in after a reconnect roles will be gone which might be very hard to explain to the average user. And I honestly can't imagine a real use case here.)
@betheg has already laid some ground work in his #725 pull request which at least from the technical side of things will allow us to implement a nice UX on top.
title: Discussion: Conference Options / MUC options

body:
## Justification Against

From the [current README](https://github.com/siacs/Conversations/blob/0.9.2/README.md):

> In the past status has been used to judge the likelihood of whether or not your messages are being read. This is no longer necessary. With Chat Markers (XEP-0333, supported by Conversations since 0.4) we have the ability to know whether or not your messages are being read. Similar things can be said for priorities. In the past priorities have been used (by servers, not by clients!) to route your messages to one specific client. With carbon messages (XEP-0280, supported by Conversations since 0.1) this is no longer necessary. Using priorities to route OTR messages isn't practical either because they are not changeable on the fly. Metrics like last active client (the client which sent the last message) are much better.
>
> Unfortunately these modern replacements for legacy XMPP features are not widely adopted. However Conversations should be an instant messenger for the future and instead of making Conversations compatible with the past we should work on implementing new, improved technologies and getting them into other XMPP clients as well.
> 
> Making these status and priority optional isn't a solution either because Conversations is trying to get rid of old behaviours and set an example for other clients.

## Justification For

I can see that the opinion is that resource priorities shouldn't be emphasized or exposed to users. I can understand how Carbons and other enhancements deprecate old approaches to managing connections. However, in some cases being able to manually set resource priorities could very helpful.

I don't ask that it go into the main menu, but hiding it away under Advanced would really be useful (at least to me).

### Environment:
* Prosody (latest 0.10 build)
* Conversations (latest)
* Yaxim (latest)
* Pidgin (latest)

### Problem I hope to solve

I am often logged into several different XMPP clients simultaneously. Conversations often acts as a secondary client whenever I have a full desktop client available (Pidgin). There are times when I know I'll soon be leaving service range and would like to drop the resource priority on Conversations prior to doing so. I often find that unless I disconnect Conversations well in advance of doing so that it ends up having a higher priority over Pidgin for example, and ends up as the default recipient of incoming messages. When those messages come in and Conversations doesn't reconnect before the mod_smacks timeout expires those incoming messages result in one or more delivery failed messages.

I suppose a workaround would be to set the priority on Pidgin if I am to remain logged in on a desktop, but if I could adjust the priority level on Conversations I feel it would solve my problem. If not a custom value, perhaps an ability to set the status which would automatically change the priority? For example if "away" then Conversations priority would take a penalty hit, perhaps -10 or so.
title: RFE: Add ability to set custom resource priority
