body:
I've been looking at the `DIGEST-MD5` code since the recent discussions and found a few improvements that could be made:

  - [ ] Caching of encoded auth tokens for subsequent authentication
  - [ ] Prevent online dictionary attacks against new registrations
  - [ ] Integrity protection
  - [ ] Confidentiality protection

There has also been talk of removing DIGEST-MD5 if fixing it was too much work, so I wanted to ask about the future of DIGEST-MD5 and whether or not any of the above listed improvements are worth the time and effort (before I started hacking away at something that would just be removed in the 1.0 release or something):

## Subsequent authentication

By caching the encoded auth message, we can cut down on the number of times we have to calculate "expensive" MD5 digests (It's not actually that expensive these days, but even so). We'd also have to verify the servers final response in this case. Basically we're trading memory usage for CPU cycles. Easy to implement.

There's a chance that this would also prevent certain offline dictionary attacks and chosen plaintext attacks, but I'm not sure. I'd have to do a bit more research there.

## Online dictionary attack prevention

This really belongs on the server, but as far as I know no server actually does it. To prevent online dictionary attacks for newly registered accounts on servers that use DIGEST-MD5, we could store a dictionary of words and common passwords, and not allow new registrations with passwords that use those words. Easy to implement.

Not worth it and belongs on the server as a matter of policy IMO, but I thought I'd mention the possibility.

## Integrity protection

Integrity protection appends an HMAC to each message in the SASL exchange which is calculated using the current session key; this way we can verify the integrity of each message when it arrives and prevent certain data modification attacks (not quite as important since we require TLS). Medium difficulty to implement.

## Confidentiality protection

Simliar to integrity protection, but also attempts to ensure the confidentiallity of the messages (again, TLS serves this purpose and does a better job). This encrypts messages using RC4 (also broken). Unsure, but probably difficult to implement.

This one is not worth the time IMO, but I list it in case there's some attack vector I'm not thinking about that this would cover (I seriously doubt it since it mandates the use of broken ciphers, and the entire auth method is already using broken hashes).

Thoughts?
title: DIGEST-MD5 potential improvements

You will see old conference names as part of the new proposal if you cancelled a previous join/create process.

body:
Currently, our IPv6 upstream link is down while IPv4 connectivity works just fine. Clients on the LAN still have v6 addresses, but trying to establish a connection to the outside yield an ICMPv6 message "route unreachable". The host at `xmpp.madduck.net` is a dual-stack and its DNS records include both `A` and `AAAA` records.

Here's a `tcpdump` from the router showing the problem:

    IP 192.168.14.97.47565 > 192.168.14.1.53: 19180+ SRV? _xmpp-client._tcp.madduck.net. (47)
    IP 192.168.14.1.53 > 192.168.14.97.47565: 19180 1/0/0 SRV xmpp.madduck.net.:5222 0 0 (83)       # the A/AAAA records for xmpp.madduck.net are piggy-backed
    IP6 2001:a60:f0fb:0:ccc0:d52d:f5a0:e583.58793 > 2001:1620:2018:2::4d6d:8b56.5222: Flags [S], seq 1557985464, win 14400, options [mss 1440,sackOK,TS val 8382397 ecr 0,nop,wscale 7], length 0
    IP6 2001:a60:f0fb::1 > 2001:a60:f0fb:0:ccc0:d52d:f5a0:e583: ICMP6, destination unreachable, unreachable route 2001:1620:2018:2::4d6d:8b56, length 88

What I'd expect now is for Conversations to fall back to IPv4, but it does not. Rather, it reports the server to be unreachable.
title: Does not fall back to IPv4 if no v6 route available

D/conversations( 1839): *****f@jabber.ccc.de: using values from dns jabberd.jabber.ccc.de[146.255.57.229]:5222
D/conversations( 1839): *****@jabber.ccc.de: TLS connection established
D/conversations( 1839): Authenticating with SCRAM-SHA-1

body:
Caches the SCRAM-SHA-1 client key and server keys for the current session (keys are not persisted across reboots) in an LruCache.

If a cache miss is detected a new key pair is automatically generated. A cache miss will occur if the user changes the username or password, or if the server changes the salt or iteration count used for PBKDF2.

Potential ways to reduce cache misses further which could be researched (we'd need some sort of data gathering mechanism that people could opt into which would probably not be worth the time) include:
  - Storing all needed info in persistant storage (larger storage footprint)
  - Using a separate LruCache for each account to prevent accounts that use random salts from forcing other accounts out of the cache quickly (larger memory footprint)
title: Cache SCRAM-SHA-1 keys for current session

body:
Pins the authentication mechanism priority used on the first connection with a given account. Afterwards, if the server presents an auth mechanism list with only lower security grade mechanisms, fail and assume it's a downgrade attack.

This uses an arbitrary "priority" instead of the auth mechanism itself so that we can fallback to authentication mechanisms of equal security value in future if required. Also, this makes the code easier to read since you can compare strict inequalities (greater than or less than) instead of just equal or not-equal, meaning you don't have to check if the pinned priority is one of many strings; you can just see if it's greater than or less than the priority of the current mechanism being used.

I arbitrarily chose to store the priority in the account's JSON blob as it was the easiest place to access and didn't require a DB migration. I'm unsure what the benefits of storing it here vs. anywhere else are. Probaby doesn't matter.

## Security considerations

Like any pinning scheme this is a trust-once security model. The first time you connect, you still have to trust that the connection is free from malicious interference.

I chose to imlement pinning at the account level instead of the server level in case a server is configured to return different authentication mechanisms for different accounts (I don't know why you'd do this, but it's not forbidden anywhere). This means that if you have multiple accounts on the same server, it's possible that pinning could prevent a downgrade attack on one, while the other has one successfully performed the first time you connect. I don't think this is really a concern as it could work the other way around too.
title: Auth mechanism pinning

body:
As @iNPUTmice said [here](https://github.com/siacs/Conversations/issues/229#issuecomment-56504936): 
>Conversations is actually pretty good a trying and retrying to send a message and making sure the server has received a message. One a message has left the device it should not be the responsibility of the client to redeliver it. Here is why: Servers have more bandwidth. **Why should a 64kbit GSM connection be bothered with 'trying three times' when the server can do this?**

It's great to have 'three tries' but I've been thinking: I can understand it if we're using a 3G network, but what if we're using Wifi? that's not a 64kbit GSM connection, so why don't increasing the number of retrying to 5 or even 10? that way, with a Wifi connection it's very difficult to lose any message, almost like using a computer (I don't know how many times uses a laptop to send a message).

I'm sorry if I'm repeating and thank you for your work!
title: Feature: Resending messages with Wifi connection.

body:
Currently, Conversations handles JIDs as strings, meaning there's a lot of duplicate, fragile, string handling code.

I've begun moving everything over using [this package](https://github.com/SamWhited/Conversations/tree/issue631/src/main/java/eu/siacs/conversations/xmpp/jid).

## Notes about the current class

  - It's immutable (meaning you can't change a JID once you've created it, you must construct a new one and it's automatically thread safe)
  - It currently represents any valid JID (bare JID, normal, or no localpart).
  - It has a lot of IDN / Unicode logic that's a bit tricky with Java (especially with a version of Dalvik using API<19; it really needs to be using byte array's and UTF8 encoding, but API<19 doesn't have Java's character encoding APIs)

### ToDo

If the current class is used, the following things need to be done:

  - [x] Remove public constructors and use a factory to construct JIDs (makes it harder to accidentally make the class mutable in the future which could lead to problems and makes the code more maintainable).
  - [ ] Figure out how to handle UTF8 encoding on API<19 devices
  - [ ] Add a way to enforce Bare JIDs

## Dependencies required

To handle IDNA and STRINGPREP, the following dependency (Apache license) is pulled in (it's essentially a wrapper around GNU IDNA if I'm not mistaken, I havne't actually looked at it other than to check that it works):

    	compile 'org.jxmpp:jxmpp-stringprep-libidn:0.4.0'

This is important as it includes the XMPP profiles of STRINGPREP (which we do not want to write ourselves... trust me).

## Discussion points

So, some discussion points:

  - JXMPP also has a JID handling library ([xmpp-jid](https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/releases/org/jxmpp/jxmpp-jid/) which we could use. I'm not a fan of the way thye've handled things, but it works and we wouldn't have to mess with it.
  - Handling JIDs separately is a big enough thing that I almost feel as if it should be broken out into a separate library (even if we write our own implementation)
  - If we do write our own implemntation, an enhancement that really MUST be made over my current attempt is a separation between normal JIDs and bare JIDs (there are all sorts of places where we need to force bare jids). Currently I'm doing tihs by a call to `Jid.getBareJid()` everywhere that it's needed; but this adds a lot of unecessary function calls. Really there should be a subclass or some sort of contract that states "this JID is always a bare JID".
  - ~~Also, a question from me for anyone who really knows their Android: Does Dalvik or ART actually do any of the optimizations that the JVM would do regarding immutable objects (eg. does it cache hashes)?~~

Thoughts?
title: Create and use JID class

body:
This branch moves the build system over to Gradle. Differences from the other pull request for this are:

  - Linting is turned on and only specific errors which need to be ignored by this project are ignored
  - Proguard is used to compress release builds
  - Submodules have been removed in favor of Maven repos / Subtree merges (makes it easier to keep track of customized dependencies)

Fixes #579

Before merging, it's probably a good idea to run `git submodule deinit libs/submodule` on all the submodules (git's a pain this way). If it still gives you trouble, remove them from the index: `git rm --cached libs/submodule`
title: Build system and library changes (Gradle / Subtree merging)

Hi,

with this pull request you switch to gradle and build all required libs from source. 
I have forked the bouncycastle and otr4j and make it build with your projekt.

You can use it with [Android Studio](https://developer.android.com/sdk/installing/studio.html)

To sign release build, create file `gradle.properties` in 
USER_HOME/.gradle or in your project root directory with this content:
```
mStoreFile=/path/to/key.store
mStorePassword=xxx
mKeyAlias=alias
mKeyPassword=xxx
```
to test it just do
`./gradlew assembleDebug`

the apk is in
`build/outputs/apk/Conversations-debug-0.8.apk`

body:
For authentication, support for `SCRAM-SHA1` (issue #71) and `SCRAM-SHA1-PLUS` (issue #74) should be added as required by XMPP Core §13.8.1 ([RFC6120][RFC6120]).

The order of preference should then be re-organized to:

  - `SCRAM-SHA1-PLUS`
  - `SCRAM-SHA1`
  - `DIGEST-MD5`
  - `PLAIN`

~~and `PLAIN` should be disallowed before TLS negotiation (and for non-TLS connections) as specified in XMPP Core §13.8.3.~~ (Conversations requires TLS as of e8bf75d79b74637d369d2a7134416c1f0852c420)

## Tasks

- [x] Prefer `DIGEST-MD5` auth over `PLAIN`
- [x] ~~Do not allow `PLAIN` auth unless TLS has been negotiated (896cd00b26190d9e1284adf9957ab0a25515a6f3)~~ redundant
- [x] Refactor authentication out into own class (#656)
- [x] Add support for `SCRAM-SHA1` and prefer it over `DIGEST-MD5` (issue #71, pull #665)
- [ ] Add support for TLS channel binding
- [ ] Add support for `SCRAM-SHA1-PLUS` and prefer it over `SCRAM-SHA1` (issue #42)

[RFC6120]: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6120.txt
title: Bring auth up to spec with XMPP Core

The idea being that you have this passphrase, or pattern, or pin that is used as the key for your data. It's required to load the app initially and then every N minutes after that. You can also force it to lock if you're going to be setting your phone down or something.
title: Lock with passphrase and encrypt all user data

body:
A friend and I are trying to use Conversations and Pidgin to replace google hangouts chat functionality.

I have
A - Pidgin
B - Pidgin
C - Phone

He has

A - Pidgin
B - Phone
C - Tablet

We can send messages from each device to the others, however sometimes messages never arrive. Is there any possible explanation for this? We've yet to discover any kind of consistent pattern.

We also lack the ability to select which resource to send from Conversations to. Occasionally a dialog will allow this but there is no allowance for arbitrary switching of resources.
title: Undelivered messages when using multiple resources

body: When building using Gradle (Gradle aware make, Android Studio import, etc.) there is a conflict between MTM `android:label` and Conversations if manifest merging is turned on. This patch fixes that, but does not affect the standard ant build. Mostly it's useful for people who want to use parts of Conversations in another Gradle aware project, or import Conversations into Android Studio.
title: Fix problem when merging manifests during a Gradle build

body:
This enables support for TLSv1.1 and 1.2.

It also adds an option to enable/disable SSLv3 (enabled by default). This option should be removed and SSLv3 disabled permanently as more servers begin supporting secure alternatives. SSLv3 is considered EOL and broken.
title: Enable TLSv1.1 and 1.2 and add option to enable/disable SSLv3

body:
The option to identify a conference by either it's name or it's subject was removed with #410. Since that all conferences are named with their subject, wich is a weird default in my opinion and leads to a situation where conferences are nearly unusable for me:

We heavily use conferences in the company and I have 20+ open conferences all the time. As all rooms show links to ticket systems or wiki pages in the subject I only see 'https://foo.bar. ...' as a name for all conferences. If I want to write to a conference I sometimes have to click on 10+ rooms until I found the one I search.

This also applies for many support/dev rooms I joined, f.e. IRC rooms on freenode. No one uses the subject to name the room. It's mostly used to display details for the room. Even the conversations muc is named as 'Join the Conversation', this generic subject could be the subject of any other room out there.

Please bring back the option to choose if the conferences should be named by their name (as default) or by their subject.
title: Plesse bring back conference naming option

body: XEP-0027 is only way to communicate through OpenPGP, it is marked as Obsolete but all OpenPGP clients implement it (f.e. Psi+, Miranda, SJ IM). XMPP team marks it as Obsolete because don't understand the simple thing: OpenPGP works with offline messages while OTR can't by design.
title: Why you don't add XEP-0027 to docs/XEP.md?

body:
Currently there is no quick way to notice that I am offline (due to loss of network connectivity or because the account is disabled). Thus it might happen that one wonders why he receives no messages, or not notice that a message cannot be send currently.

Hence I suggest to subtly visualise the fact that Conversations is currently in "offline" mode, e.g. by turning the bright green colour into grey.
title: Visualise own online status

body:
There is this annoying thing I call the the "WhatsApp-Effect": People constanty get messages and look at their phone, because it could be this important message by that important person. Thus they appear absent to the people around them, which is obviously rude. Their other option is to ignore their phone and its messages, which might also not be what they want.

It seems very easy to be dragged into this – since I enabled mobile internet recently and started using Conversations, it also happens to me sometimes…

Thus I would ask for some way to tell my online contacts that I only want to receive actually important messages. Putting Conversations into an always-enabled Do-Not-Disturb mode would be a start. Another option would be to not notify the user at all, unless someone actually calls for his attention using XEP-0224 (Attention). I am also open for other creative ideas.
title: Ability to signal "only important messages" to my contacts

body:
Yes, I read the whole "Where can I see the status of my contacts? How can I set a status or priority" chapter. Just few comments on your points:
"Setting them automatically does not provide quality results either. Keyboard or mouse activity as indicator for example fails when the user is just looking at something (reading an article, watching a movie)."
The quality of autostatuses are good enough for real life. When I read article, I make scrolling which resets Away status. When I watch the movie, fullscreen is sensed, making my autostatus set to DND.
"Furthermore automatic setting of status always implies an impact on your privacy. " 
Let me choose by myself to send my status updates or to not for particular buddy, you already have it implemented in the buddy's properties.
"Are you sure you want everybody in your contact list to know that you have been using your computer at 4am?!"
Not for everybody but for some of them I want. See prev. comment.

Please consider possible lowering of status restrictions, especially for those who knows what they do.

1) Please show online/offline/other each buddy status directly in the "Converstations" and "Start chat" tabs. It is needed to determine response time, f.e. for online contacts I expect fast answer but for offline it can be delayed for days. For DND contacts I'll wait untill their status is changed, etc.

2) Autopriority. Priority is needed to determine where to send message when both desktop computer and smartphone are connected to the same account. See like Xabber implements autostatuses and autopriority depending on autostatus (lots of desktop clients do the same too). With priorities are properly set on both devices, I can walk with smartphone leaving desktop client turned on, without fear that I got the messages on desktop (i.e. unnoticed).
title: Few comments about autostatuses & autopriorities.

body:
Converstations seems to lack XEP-0071 support. My use case is to deliver monitoring messages (from Nagios) through XMPP clients (Conversations), which are preferably color coded. Conversations only displays the plaintext part of XEP-0071 messages, so no HTML/colors.

Is there any change this could be implemented?
title: XEP-0071 (XHTML-IM) support

body:
The same setup works about month ago, during this month several OpenKeychain versions are uploaded to the Market and autoupdated. I test with today's version 2.9.2 and found that:
1) Sending messages with OpenPGP is broken, the app says it can't send the message and not say a reason why. Sending without OpenPGP for the same contact works.
2) Receiving messages with OpenPGP works.
3) The same passphrase can be cached two times, one from "Announce OpenPGP key" from account options and another one from received message itself, i.e. it does not detect previously cached passphrase.
There is a note that 
\* Intent API has changed
in OpenKeychain 2.9.1, it looks suspicious. Perhaps there are more incompatibilities with changed API, I don't test through.
title: OpenPGP is broken with recent OpenKeychain versions

Hi,
I'm just implementing a preview for messages containing just an image url. I have done it only for group chats for now, as there is no other way for sending images yet.
This code is not ready yet, but I just wanted to let others know that I am working on this, and ask for comments.
For example, should there be a preference to switch this on/off, and what should be the default?
Also, is this the right location to place this feature? And there most likely is a better way to look out for images than my very simple regex...
Anyway, I'll continue on this in the next days and let you know.

Yours, Max


![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/388142/4179766/ffc232e2-36d4-11e4-8cb2-74ff2bb86dad.png)
title: Image url preview in MUC conversations

body:
Hi,

the first part is fix typo for word contains receive.

The second part sends <request xmlns='urn:xmpp:receipts'/> so we got an received when client is using
XEP-0184 and not only when a client uses 'XEP-0333: Chat Markers' then when we received the 'received' message marks the timestamp with an green color. So we always know when the message arrived.
When then the 'displayed ' messages arrives then change the color of the timestamp to blue.

The problem is that i know of no who is using XEP-0333 but a lot which uses XEP-0184
and the missing indicator whether a message has arrived or not.

greets
title: XEP-0184: send 'request' and not only 'received' messages also mark the receiving.

If I log into an account with Conversations and then try to start an OTR session to that account from a different OTR-enabled device, then Conversations crashes.

body:
If queryDNS faisl to find SRV entry, it uses Google DNS (8.8.8.8) as a fallback.
This fallback is a problem as DNS traffic from 8.8.8.8 is not accessible on all networks. It could be blocked by the network admin for example to prevent DNS restrictions escape.

A better fallback would be to use the @ DNS entry rather than SRV if the SRV entry could not be found.
title: Fallback if SRV cannot be found.

body:
I think a great feature for Conversations would be the support for groups chat. I mean that if you send a message to a group, it will arrive to every person subscribed to that group.

The big difference with XMPP rooms, is that with groups there's no need to be connected to a room if you want to receive the message, so if the person is disconnected, then the next time he connects will receive the message. That's a big advantage compared with XMPP rooms, because in rooms you need to be connected to view the messages that people write.

It's a feature similar to WhatsApp. And it would be great if you can send images/files to a group. (that's what every XMPP client for Android needs since much time ago, but no one has implemented it yet).
title: Feature: Support for groups, like WhatsApp (Not rooms)

body:
So that this works, Conversations needs a client signature. 

--

Example:

There's one JID but two clients... Conversations and Jitsi. 

Conversations has default priority = 0, my computer client is Jitsi with priority = 50. If somebody is sending me a message, it should be sent automatically to the highest priority, no questions where to send. 

Great, I'm sitting in front of my computer, so it's comfortable to write there. Now I exit Jitsi or shutdown my computer, so I'll get the message on Conversations. 

( if not using OTR and using carbon copies, then I can continue on Conversations with the complete history) 

Problem: What if I forget to exit Jitsi? 
Solution : I'm using the AFK feature, so I'm not available. In this case, when using OTR, Conversations would see "Oh, the higher priority isn't available, then I'll send it to the lower one." 

If using carbon copy, then it doesn't matter. 

But: If there are 2 Conversations clients with one JID, then the user can be asked, if OTR is enabled. If not, then send carbon copy. 

--

I hope I've explained it clearly. There are a lot "if, thens", I'm not a developer, maybe my logic is not correct.
title: Automatically send to highest priority, but ask JID if more than 1 Conversations clients

body:
Scenery :
1x JID
2x Clients = 1x Jitsi, 1x Conversations

When sending a file to one JID, if Conversations would have a client signature, another Conversations client could send the file automatically to Conversations. 

This would fit to the minimalistic and clean UI, instead of asking to which JID to send.

Often the other users are sending to the wrong JID or just trying or asking me or they just give up. 

If there's no Conversations client, it could tell the user "Sorry, there's no compatible client for file transfer." instead of sending, but it never reaches the other client. 
There are only two handful xmpp clients, that are used often, so the signature list would be easy to update. 

Xabber and jTalk / jTalkMod are sending their signature. I think Jitsi, too. 

I don't think that the file transfer problem, with other clients, will be solved soon.
title: Client signature - Send files to Conversations only

If you get a 'private' message in a MUC, the message will be displayed in the (public) MUC.
No one else can read it but you do not know whether it was private.
So if you answer to this (private) mesage, you write in the (public) MUC.
Btw. it is not possibe to write a private message to someone in a MUC.
Private messages in MUCs should open a new conversation.

An idea of how to start a private chat in a MUC should be to tab on a member in the 'conference details' - 'other members' menu.

body:
I have read about presence being too hard and useless for normal users and I just wanted to give you some points to reconsider integrating presence in Conversations.

Conversations is a mobile-oriented XMPP client, but we must remember XMPP is a widely used standard, used in many different environments. Being presence one of the core features, would it not be sensible to implement it? At least for compatibility with every other client out there, I think it is.

Personally, when I use presence I feel like it's very useful to me. For example, if I'm working and I set my presence "Occupied (At work)", nobody feels like I'm deliberately ignoring them, but it could happen if I'm always "Online". Unneeded social inconveniences like [this](http://youtu.be/D5zaF61DeJQ) did not exist until somebody decided that a "last connection" and a "double check" was better than presence. Indeed it is good, but users must be able to choose.

Also for OTR chats and jingle calls (for the future) it's vital to know the user's presence, and knowing it in group chats is very useful too.

Of course, don't forget the most useful and privacy-aware presence status ever: "Invisible". It was a bliss on many circumstances, and it's been away of mobile messengers since the GTalk times! Bringing that back would be by itself a reason to convince people to switch to Conversations.

And about being too hard for users... Nowadays everyone's grandma has a photo in Whatsapp, a status message with emoticons, and knows how to disable the "last connection" info. It's not about users, it's about simple and self-explanatory UIs and sensible defaults.

For example, Conversations could work just as it is right now, but showing a colored bubble for contacts (you could make it optional and keep it off by default to keep current behavior) and add a little set of options (maybe by account):

- Presence (this could be by account):
  - Always "Online" (default choice, as it is right now).
  - Automatic away (If Conversations is opened in the foreground: "online". Else: "away").
  - Occupied.
  - Invisible.
  - Disconnected (It fits here, I think).

As a sidenote, I remember a couple of things from GTalk that can be considered regarding easiness:

1. When talking to an offline contact like "This user is offline. Messages will be delivered when he becomes online". This can also help users to remember that they can send messages to offline users.
2. Presence bubbles were shown in the address book app.
title: Any chance to reconsider presence?

body:
Hi,

When you send a message but you can't conncect to the server, Conversations don't let you know the real date when the message is sent.
In the other way, when you receive a message you don't know if the message was delayed.

I put an example:

Person A, sent a message at 10.20 but was sent to the server at 10.45 because of poor connection. Conversations doesn't shows that message was real sent at 10.45, only shows that the message was sent at 10.20.

Person B, received the message at 10.45. Conversations doesn't show that the message from A was real sent at 10.20, only shows that was received at 10.45.

Xabber for example show both dates for A and B.

I don't know if the XEP-0203: Delayed Delivery, could help to do this?

Thank you.
title: Delayed sent messages and delayed delivery messages

If I use OTR from Conversations, no message is copied to Pidgin but the other way around, I receive a message sent from me that is encrypted via OTR. Obviously, Conversations cannot decrypt the message but instead of showing an information message like "wrong key" or "sent from another instance" it show the text of the message: "?OTR:AAM.....".

body:
Allow users to display full time stamps. Also converts time stamps to user locale-sensitive java.text.DateFormat.

This still has one preference, so that users can have a standard short time stamp, or enable a full (long) time stamp.
title: New time stamps

body:
Added ability to long press single messages, and copy text or delete a
single message (this menu can open options for forwarding messages as well, if that's something anyone is interested in).

Also added new preferences for time stamps, so users can use 12-hr/24-hr,
as well as display full time stamps (including the date) if they wish.

I'm open to implementing even more options for time stamps, if there's a need. I know the design principles are to keep things simple, but forcing a 24-hour time stamp doesn't seem fair.

body:
Some DNS servers do not reply to queries of type ANY. The result is, that the app does not connect to the jabber accounts an marks the account as offline.
Even the public DNS server of google (8.8.8.8) does not answer to queries of the type ANY.
You should use type SRV for the query instead which will be answered correctly by the DNS servers.

To reproduce simply try the following commands:
```
dig @8.8.8.8 _xmpp-client._tcp.jabber.ccc.de ANY
dig @8.8.8.8 _xmpp-client._tcp.jabber.ccc.de SRV
```
title: DNS query for _xmpp-client._tcp.[...] should use the type SRV instead of ANY

body:
### Steps to reproduce:

1. Connect with resource Mobile to a server with stream management.
2. Change resource to Phone
3. Swipe Conversations out of recent apps list
4. Start it again.
5. On server: Two connections from Conversations, with resource mobile and phone
6. Send from another client messages to /mobile and /phone
7. Both messages stanzas will be acknowledged, stream timeout timer never starts.

### Versions

- Server was ejabberd 14.05
- Conversations master @ 1db807ef585ef19f96038aeea72acfeada901e66
title: After resource change and restart Conversations maintains two connections.

body:
Server administrators might set multiple SRV records. 
It might be the case that the address of the first SRV record isn't reachable.
Conversations should then try to use the next one.

The status "Account.STATUS_SERVER_NOT_FOUND" shouldn't be set before trying all SRV records.
title: Try all SRV records when connecting to a server

body:
It seems there's a small window where message can get lost during reconnect. I was able to duplicate this issue with the following steps:

1. Enable WIFI and mobile data connection.
1. Wait and verify that Conversations establishes the connection.
1. Disable wifi
    1. Send messages
    1. The first messages will be instantly marked as "send", but never arrive
    1. Continue sending messages
    1. After few seconds, messages will me marked as "sending..." and then "send".
       These messages will arrive.
1. Enable Wifi
1. Repeat messages sending

It seem that it's easier to reproduce while switching back to wifi. I tried that with two accounts on different servers. Both accounts where configured in Conversations. The server software is ejabberd 14.05.
title: Lost messages after reconnect

body:
These few files will allow developers using Android Studio to contribute!

Gradle also makes it super easy to bootstrap a build environment.

```
git clone https://github.com/siacs/Conversations.git
cd Conversations
git submodule update --init --recursive
./gradlew assembleDebug
```

You don't have to have gradle installed -- The `gradlew` script downloads the version of gradle prescribed in `gradle-wrapper.properties` to a local project cache in `./.gradle/`. This way all contributors are guaranteed to be using the same build tools!

Love your work. Cheers!
title: Add Gradle build files

body:
Hi,
you might be interest in some changes in my forked repository [0].
The SSL fingerprint verification at the moment is not that nice, as it only relies on SHA1 hash (since the chain is irrelevant, so a simple SHA1 collision would circumvent this check). Furthermore not everyone likes the commercial x509 PKI[1], so why not ignore all the system certificates instead and let the user choose? Since the upstream application is probably not only targeted to advanced user, this "use custom PKI/trust anchor" stuff could be a setting and disabled by default.
Due other changes I cant make an official pull request. In my fork I removed support for GPG as I dont think it shall be used for IM purposes.
Best regards,
Leon
[0] https://github.com/lwi/Conversations/commit/bdc64d30bb0a3e9d05a391feed695c96dd6ac6bd
[1] http://www.thoughtcrime.org/blog/authenticity-is-broken-in-ssl-but-your-app-ha/
title: Custom X509 trust anchor for advanced user

I recently changed from Xabber to Conversations. I like it very much, but my friends which still use Xabber now don't see the green check marks upon successful delivery when they send me a message.
I found out that Xabber requests message delivery receipts (XEP-0184). So I wrote a quick implementation, that announces the message delivery receipt feature and also sends this receipt, if the sender requested it.
title: answer to message delivery receipts (XEP-0184)

body:
I sign my xmpp connections with my pgp keys. Other clients now see the last signing time, maybe "27/04/2013 12:00 [$keyid]. If I now use conversations some days, even if I rebooted the phone or killed conversation, that sign will stay until I manually start the PGP announcenment again. 

In my eyes this undermines the security and use of the signed connections as there is no need to re-enter my passphrase if I start conversations again. So everyone who gets my phone could use this singed connection and pretend to be me.

It would be nice if there would be an option (or the default behaviour) to renew the pgp announcement everytime conversations starts, if PGP is used. That's what other clients (f.g. psi/psi-plus) do. In case of theft or unauthorized use of my phone friends could see that my mobile connection is no longer signed and they would be warned.
title: PGP reannouncement on app start

body:
I have two jabber accounts in conversations and two pgp keys for them in OpenKeyChain.

To get that configured I sent one encrypted message to account1 and assigned key1 in the dialog, afterwards I did the same with account2 and key2.

Then, some days later, I hit "renew pgp announcement" on "account1" and now I am asked to assign a PGP key to the account "default", not "account1". As there are only my two keys I have to choose one of them.

this results in 3 registered conversations accounts in openkeychain:

default > key1 assigned
account1 > key1 assigned
account2 > key2 assigned

In the end I have now a mixed up setting as account2 is signed with key1 (I think because it's the key assigned to account "default").

Expected behaviour:

If I hit "renew" on an account I should be asked to assign a key to this account. I don't know for what usecase a "default" one is needed.

Some counts for a new setup. I should be able to configure both accounts. The only way to avoid the creation of that "default" account is to "configure" by sendign encrypted mails to every account.

thanks for the work on conversations, I like it! :)

Best,
Til
title: PGP - renew announcement does not use the selected account

body:
SecuXabber has a nice feature to inform other user about own position:
- select menu item "send own position"
- this evaluates own geolocation using GPS and libwlocate
- position is sent to other end encrpted
- there Nominatim is used to convert geolocation to an address
- address is shown as current position of other user

Code for Nominatim access and address decoding can be found in https://sourceforge.net/p/secuxabber/code/ci/master/tree/src/com/secuxabber/android/encryption/

libwlocate for fast and easy position evaluation can be found at https://sourceforge.net/p/libwlocate/code/ci/master/tree/master/android/LocDemo/src/com/vwp/libwlocate/
title: XEP-0080: User Location support

body:
Using GPG for end-to-end encryption is nice but not useful since user has to re-enter password for keystore from time to time. Beside of that it is not easy to understand how it has to be used (and therefore impossible to handle for not so experienced users). Better solution can be found in SecuXabber
- key pair is generated on start up automatically
- as long as no encryption is active users are warned with a short text message
- users can exchange their public keys via Bluetooth easily - this is the secure way since they can verify the key comes from right person
- user is notified when message has arrived at other end

Code can be found in https://sourceforge.net/p/secuxabber/code/ci/master/tree/src/com/secuxabber/android/encryption/
title: Add custom Encryption Key handling as in SecuXabber

body:
This is an experimental patch. I'm sharing it because I'd need verification by multiple persons that it either works or that it has flaws. Do not pull it before we got feedback.

This patch adds a time_tick listener and externalize the account connect/reconnect loop into a "checkAccounts" function.

XMPPConnection gets a retryCounter which symbolizes the retry interval.

I've successfully switched from wifi to gsm and the logic kicked in and reconnected me. I've no idea how well it will work "on the go".
title: Aggressive account checking and early reconnect with a 1.5 ^ n retry

body:
One of the design goals of Conversations is to require as little permissions as possible. Yet we require permissions like READ_CONTACTS which - if we were a malicious app could mean I significant impact on privacy. We can not get rid of that permission completely because I really like to have pictures of my contacts. (And also the full names) However Conversations was designed in a way that these permissions are only used at some very specific parts within the code. It would be very easy to wrap those parts with a try-catch and have them return empty values (which then would appear to the rest of Conversations as if these contacts wouldn't exist. (And one would see the usual coloured letters)

The goal is that you could very simply remove the one <require-permission /> line from the Manifest and have Conversations behave as usual.
title: Make Conversations not crash on missing permissions

Add compression support.

1. Add UI parts and Account option
2. Add ZLibInputStream - an InflaterInputStream with a fixed available method
3. Add ZLibOutputStream - an DeflaterOutputStream with partial flush support (method was hidden till API level 18, it's now "unhidden" and available since nearly forever)
4. Add an ability to get the Input/Output Streams (needed to wrap them inside an ZLib Stream)
5. Add a minimal fix to UIHelper: I have some contacts in my roster without an empty name... This crashed Conversations

body:
I was required to implement some changes to the OpenPGP API to get it accepted for K-9 Mail.
Unfortunately some of these changes were breaking changes.
Now that my pull request has been merged into K-9 Mail (https://github.com/k9mail/k-9/pull/457), I promise that in the near future no big API changes are planned.

So, to work with OpenKeychain 2.5 (should appear in some hours on Google Play), you would need to update to the current openpgp-api-library.
I now also have a small documentation wiki page here: https://github.com/openpgp-keychain/openpgp-keychain/wiki/OpenPGP-API

If you have questions, don't hesitate to write me.
title: OpenPGP API version 3

body:
Hi,

This patch pulls the fix in NameUtil as well as a shortcut to use a provided IPv4 address on connect. I'm not yet sure if I should also use an IPv6 address, it's at least provided.

IP addresses are randomized before use. DNS should do the same, but there are known exceptions.

This shortcut won't work if your SRV record points to a CNAME. But this is not recommended anyway and it won't break.

The only breakage would be if the client has IPv6 connectivity only. I'm not sure if this is an issue right now...
title: Add ability to use a provided ipv4 address on connect

body:
When adding a "new account" one has to type in the complete FQDN to identify the xmpp server in question. Since typing on mobile keyboards is hard, Conversations should support the user in entering the domain names of known XMPP-Servers.

There are some directories of jabber servers that could be used as a source of known servers:

- <http://www.jaim.at/server/>
- <https://list.jabber.at/>
- <https://xmpp.net/directory.php>
- <http://www.jabberes.org/servers/>

This could be done with auto completion, though one had to type the whole subdomain: "jabber" could mean "jabber.freenet.de" or "jabber.ccc.de", so substring matching could improve that "ccc" would definately mean "jabber.ccc.de" and "freenet" would definately mean "jabber.freenet.de". Substring matching on the TLD would also avoid confusion about popular subdomains like "im.example.com", "jabber.example.com" or "xmpp.example.com".

See also [the comment of @rtreffer on this](https://github.com/siacs/Conversations/issues/34#issuecomment-39250560)
title: Suggest known XMPP servers

body:
Sometimes, the UI seems to get temporarily detached from the backend. This means that a conversation view will not get updated with new incoming or outgoing messages. It is still possible to type outgoing messages and send them, and they will be transmitted, but the news messages do not appear in the UI. New incoming messages do not appear in the UI either, but notifications for them will appear. This can be "fixed", by reopening the conversation view in some way, e.g. navigating to the conversation list and then reopening the conversation.

This issue has been known for a while, but we haven't been able to track down the cause due to problems with reproducibility. This problem only seems to appear (for me at least) when entering the app from a notification selected from the lock screen. It also does not seem to affect everyone, so if someone can't reproduce it themselves, I'd be happy to provide any additional information or try out some experimental builds and report back.
title: Ui "detaches" from backend service

body:
Awesome project BTW!  I was also working on an XMPP client which looked beautiful but due to time constraints I never managed to get any meaningful progress on it. Then I came across this project which incorporates much of what I wanted to implement.

However, one improvement which I would like to suggest is the splitting up of XMPPConnection class into several more manageable classes. Right now it's a super class which does everything in one class. However, a better more managable design would be splitting this up into several classes as so:
* a wrapper class which wraps the connection process using a thread
* the actual connection class which carries out the connection and then starts parsing
* a main parser class which accepts the next tag and chooses the sub-parser based on the tag's info
* several parser class which actually do the reponses etc.

This is very similar to a design of an IRC library I wrote for Android github.com/tilal6991/Relay - the basic structure is the same as I what I suggest here.

Awesome work again
title: Source code: refactor XMPPConnection into several classes

body:
I've been looking into XMPP implementations and whether they verify the source of iq replies. See http://mail.jabber.org/pipermail/jdev/2014-January/089824.html and http://mail.jabber.org/pipermail/jdev/2014-January/089838.html for more discussion.

https://github.com/siacs/Conversations/blob/master/src/eu/siacs/conversations/xmpp/XmppConnection.java#L650 appears to contain no code that checks whether the received iq's `from` attribute matches the used `to` attribute. This can lead to spoofing of iq replies (spoofing rosters, etc.). The use of randomly generated `id` values makes this harder, but not impossible.

More importantly, https://github.com/siacs/Conversations/blob/7d505856a0009464eb9e2523743c1bba6241a217/src/eu/siacs/conversations/services/XmppConnectionService.java#L322 does not check for roster pushes whether they come from the server or not. Any incoming iq with an `<query xmlns='jabber:iq:roster'>` child is handled as if it were a push from the server. I have not verified this using the client itself, only by inspection of the source code. These replies should come from your own bare JID, but some other servers out there send it from the bare domain or from your own full JID.
title: iq 'from' attributes are not checked and roster pushes are not verified

body:
**Steps to reproduce:**
* Have a previously established OTR session with a buddy
* Switch off OTR in the app
* Continue writing messages

**Actual results:**
The messages are sent unencrypted, but the OTR channel is not closed by the app. This produces potentially confusing notifications of unexpectedly unencrypted messages at the other party's client.

**Expected results:**
The app should close the OTR channel to notify the other communication party of the user's choice to continue communicating without encryption.
title: Close OTR channel when switching to plain text communication
Use the vCard Nickname.Name as display name if it exists

title: fetch roster

body:
##Introduction
 

##Purpose
As a user with a large address book with many persons having almost the same name I use alias to differentiate the people.  The APP could check the alias field and use it, if it is set as displayed name in the NewConversationActivity.
title: Use the alias field from the addressbook
